newsitem.title: JAPAN: Hanshin Bank capital adequacy ratio seen at 3.2%.
newsitem.headline: Hanshin Bank capital adequacy ratio seen at 3.2%.

text.p: Hanshin Bank Ltd, a medium-sized regional bank based in Kobe, western Japan, said on Friday that its capital adequacy ratio at the end of March would be around 3.2 percent.
At the end of September 1996, the ratio was 4.07 percent, a bank executive told reporters.

Japan is scheduled to introduce formal capital adequacy standards in April 1998 under which banks operating only in Japan must have a capital adequacy ratio of at least four percent to be considered "adequately capitalised".
Under the new system, the Finance Ministry can order a bank to take action to improve its health if the ratio falls below four percent.
Hanshin Bank said earlier on Friday it planned to write off 20.6 billion yen worth of problem loans in the year to March 31, and would post parent current and net losses due to the write-offs.
